document.id: Pueblo de San Ildefonso Council Res. No. SI-R25-005
document.heading: PUEBLO DE SAN ILDEFONSO COUNCIL RESOLUTION NO. SI-R25-005
Act Amending Election Law Absentee Voting Provisions
document.preamble: At a duly called meeting of the Council of San Ildefonso Pueblo on the 26th day of June, 2025, the following law was adopted:

recital.text: the Pueblo de San Ildefonso ("Pueblo") is a sovereign and self-governing Tribe, recognized as such by the United States of America; and
the sovereign authority of the Pueblo is vested in its Council and Governor; and
the Pueblo's Election Law governs the scope and process for tribal elections; and

the Election Law was amended in 2023 to allow absentee voting by students and active military personnel who will be out of state at the time of a tribal election, and for homebound tribal elders who are not be able to physically appear at the tribal polling place; and

the Election Commission has proposed changes to the Election Law absentee voting provisions to allow for absentee voting by tribal member spouses of active military personnel who will be out of state at the time of a tribal election, as well as clarifying that absentee voting for homebound elders is for those elders who reside within the Pueblo's boundaries, as shown on Attachment A hereto; and

the Council has reviewed the proposed changes to the Election Law and determines it is in the best interest of the Pueblo to authorize amendment of the Election Law absentee voting provisions regarding spouses of active military personnel and homebound elders.

recital.conjunction: NOW THEREFORE BE IT RESOLVED THAT
recital.text: the Council hereby enacts the attached law entitled the "ACT AMENDING ELECTION LAW ABSENTEE VOTING PROVISIONS."

procedural-data.text: The foregoing resolution was duly voted upon by the Council on June 26, 2025, at a meeting with a vote of 6 in favor, 0 opposed, 3 abstaining and 1 absent (Governor presiding and not voting) pursuant to the authority vested in the Council by the Agreement of the Pueblo de San Ildefonso.

para.heading: Eligibility.
para.text: Any eligible voter who meets at least one of the following requirements shall be entitled to vote in any election by absentee ballot:
The voter is age fifty-five (55) or older, resides within the Pueblo boundaries, and is homebound and unable to appear physically at the polling place on the date of the election; or
The voter is an out-of-state college student or in the military and unable to appear physically at the polling place on the date of the election; or
The voter is in the military, or is the spouse of a military member, and unable to appear physically at the polling place on the date of the election.

The eligible voter must request an absentee ballot by submitting a written request, either in the form of a letter or completed Absentee Ballot Request form, to the Election Commission. All requests must be signed by the requesting voter. The voter may be asked for proof they meet the eligibility requirements.

The voter may request an absentee ballot by submitting the written request to the Election Commission either by hand-delivery to the Election Commission office, mail to the Election Commission’s listed address, or emailing a scanned request to the Election Commission’s listed email address.

All absentee ballot requests must be received by the Election Commission no later than 4:30 p.m. on the 15th day before the date of the Election. Requests that are not received by the deadline or that do not meet any of the requirements will not be accepted or processed. It is the sole responsibility of the requesting voter to ensure that the voter's mailing address is correct on their written request.

In the event of a Special Election to fill a vacancy in an elected position, an eligible voter may request an absentee ballot up to 12:00 noon the day before the Special Election. However, due to the short timeframe of the Special Election, the Election Commission cannot guarantee that the requesting voter will timely receive the absentee ballot or that the returned ballot will be received by the Election Commission by the deadline and voters are encouraged to submit absentee ballot requests as early as possible.

The voter shall complete the absentee ballot and return the absentee ballot in accordance with the stated instructions. Ballots may be returned by U.S. mail, private delivery service, or by hand-delivery to the Election Commission office.
The deadline for receipt of cast absentee ballots shall be 4:30p.m. on the day before the election.

Absentee ballots that do not bear the voter’s signature or are not properly enclosed in the envelopes or do not meet the requirements to cast an absentee ballot or are received after the stated deadline shall not be opened, processed or counted.

attachment.heading: ACT AMENDING ELECTION LAW ABSENTEE VOTING PROVISIONS

section.heading: Short Title
section.text: This enactment shall be known as "Act Amending Election Law Absentee Voting Provisions" ("Act").

section.heading: Purpose
section.text: The purpose of this Act is to authorize the amendment of the Pueblo's Election Law absentee voting provisions in tribal elections to include spouses of active duty military members and to clarify the eligibility for homebound elders.

section.heading: Findings
section.text: The Council hereby finds and declares that:

para.text: The Pueblo's Election Law governs the scope and process for tribal elections.

The Election Law was amended in 2023 to allow absentee voting by students and active military personnel who will be out of state at the time of a tribal election, and for homebound tribal elders who are not be able to physically appear at the tribal polling place.

The Election Commission has proposed changes to the Election Law absentee voting provisions to allow for absentee voting by tribal member spouses of active military personnel who will be out of state at the time of a tribal election, as well as clarifying that absentee voting for homebound elders is for those elders who reside within the Pueblo's boundaries.

The Council has reviewed the proposed changes to the Election Law and determines it is in the best interest of the Pueblo to authorize amendment of the Election Law absentee voting provisions regarding spouses of active military personnel and homebound elders.
The Election Law absentee voting provisions shall be amended to allow absentee voting in tribal elections in the limited situations as shown in Attachment A hereto.
The Election Commission is authorized to take such actions as deemed necessary to carry out the intent of this Resolution.
